article_html:
Sorry, your browser is unable to play this video.Please install Adobe Flash ™ and try again. Alternatively upgrade to a modern browser.

It’s a girl, but the guessing game over the Princess of Cambridge continued today during the wait for the announcement of the name chosen for the youngest royal, born on Saturday.

As the first official photograph of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge’s daughter dominated front pages, the names Alice, Charlotte and late frontrunner Olivia were among the favourites.

There was speculation there could be an announcement as early as Sunday.

After her first official photo call, sleeping soundly in her mother’s arms on the steps of the private Lindo Wing at St Mary’s hospital, Paddington, the young princess – the first in 25 years and fourth in line to the throne – was taken to the family’s London home in Kensington Palace.

The Cambridges will stay briefly in London before returning to Anmer Hall, their country home on the Queen’s Sandringham estate in Norfolk, in the next day or two.

The Prince of Wales, who had previously spoken of his wish for a granddaughter, was among visitors to arrive at Kensington Palace on Sunday. Charles drove through the palace gates with the Duchess of Cornwall in the passenger seat shortly after 1pm. The couple were said to be “absolutely delighted” at the news.

They joined Kate’s mother, Carole Middleton, and sister, Pippa, who were the first guests of the day, arriving at 11.15am.

It seemed likely the Queen, who is at Sandringham, would not meet her fifth great grandchild, who was born at 8.34am on 2 May weighing 8lbs 3oz, until the family is in Norfolk.

Sorry, your browser is unable to play this video.

Facebook

Twitter

Pinterest

 Stuart Heritage leans down over the royal cot and fills in Prince William and the Duchess of Cambridge’s daughter on her very important family

Charlotte has a long royal pedigree and was the name of George III’s queen, portrayed by Helen Mirren in the 1994 film The Madness of King George. Alice, meanwhile, was the name of the Duke of Edinburgh’s mother and also a daughter of Queen Victoria.

Alice was favoured by town crier Tony Appleton, president of the Guild of International Millennium Town Criers, who, with the permission of the couple, brought some colourful theatrics to the steps of the Lindo Wing with a traditional bell and scroll proclamation of birth when it was announced at 11.10am.

It provided some spectacle for the assembled crowd as they waited for the moment when the duke, duchess and their newborn appeared.

A bonus for the hardcore super fans, some who had camped out for up to two weeks, was the appearance of a slightly bewildered Prince George, aged 21 months. William, who was present at the birth, had briefly left the hospital left to collect his son from Kensington Palace and bring him to meet his sister for the first time.

Facebook

Twitter

Pinterest

 Prince William arrives with Prince George at the Lindo Wing following the birth of his second child at St Mary’s hospital in London. Photograph: Samir Hussein/WireImage

So fiercely protective of the toddler’s privacy are his parents, it was his first public outing in Britain since he was born at the same hospital wing, though media access was granted on tour in Australia and New Zealand.

Perhaps slightly overwhelmed by the massed rank of cameras trained on him, George seemed reluctant to walk, putting up his arms to be carried by his father, who coaxed him to give a royal wave.

The event was as low key as was possible with hordes of international media present; done and dusted in 12 hours, from the duchess’s admission in “early stages of labour” at 6am, to her discharge shortly after 6pm, having given birth at 8.34am.

There were no comments from the couple, other than William saying they were “very happy” in answer to questions shouted by journalists.

Mindful that St Mary’s is a working hospital, the couple were keen to minimise disruption.

As well as the people waiting outside the hospital, a crowd had been gathering from early morning at Buckingham Palace where, after the birth’s announcement on the Kensington Palace Twitter account, a formal proclamation was pinned to an ornate easel on the forecourt.

Facebook

Twitter

Pinterest

 Two workers return to Buckingham Palace after placing an easel in the forecourt to announce the birth of a baby girl to the Duchess of Cambridge. Photograph: Pool/Reuters

A long queue quickly formed as people waited to get a glimpse of the brief bulletin signed by the senior medical team, led by consultant obstetrician Guy Thorpe-Beeston, surgeon-gynaecologist to the household, who delivered the princess.

Messages of congratulation poured in from around the world, and from all political party leaders who broke briefly from campaigning for the general election.

The Tower of London and Trafalgar Square turned pink to mark the occasion, with the BT tower running the ticker “It’s a girl” and Royal Mail introducing a special postmark.

Gun salutes will be fired in Hyde Park and at the Tower of London on Monday to mark the birth.

The Royal Collection Trust was quick to capitalise on the birth, unveiling a range of official chinaware – a coffee mug for £19.95, a pillbox for £29.00, and £39 tankard and £45 plate. The design incorporates the lion and unicorn from the Royal Arms, in the style of figures from a carousel, the couple’s coronet and a pattern of oak leaves from the Middleton family’s coat of arms.

title: The royal baby has arrived, now the wait for a princess's name
